docs.lead_paragraph: A state judge has ordered a health maintenance organization to pay for 24-hour nursing care it had denied for a 5-month-old baby who survives on breathing and feeding tubes. Caitlin King of Butler was born Oct. 12 at Hackensack University Medical Center and could neither breathe nor eat normally, leading to a five-week stay in the hospital's intensive-care unit. Hospital physicians said the baby would need constant nursing care to keep the airway and feeding tube open once she came home, said the baby's father, Tom King.

headline.main: H.M.O. Told to Provide 24-Hour Care for Baby

docs.abstract: New Jersey Superior Court Judge R Benjamin Cohen orders health maintenance organization University Health Plans to pay for 24-hour nursing care it had denied for 5-month-old Caitlin King, who survives on breathing and feeding tubes (S)
docs.snippet: A state judge has ordered a health maintenance organization to pay for 24-hour nursing care it had denied for a 5-month-old baby who survives on breathing and feeding tubes.    Caitlin King of Butler was born Oct. 12 at Hackensack University Medical...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, dozens of teaching hospitals across New York State embraced an unusual pilot program to ease the nationwide glut of physicians. The Federal Government would pay bonuses to the hospitals if they trained fewer doctors, just as it once paid corn farmers not to grow corn. But half those hospitals have now dropped out of the plan after finding that they cannot function without the low-cost labor provided by doctors in training, known as residents.

headline.main: Many Hospitals in New York Quit Plan for Fewer Doctors

docs.abstract: Dozens of teaching hospitals in New York State in 1997 embraced unusual pilot program under which Federal Government agreed to pay bonuses to hospitals if they trained fewer doctors; half those hospitals have dropped out of plan after finding that they cannot function without low-cost labor provided by doctors in training; development, which comes even as Government is planning to expand New York program nationwide, raises doubts about Federal efforts to curb number of doctors in nation; pilot program in New York was devised by Greater New York Hospital Association officials; it was approved by Health Care Financing Administration, Federal agency that pays for training of physicians (M)
